docs.snippet: In Raymond Carver's story ''A Small, Good Thing,'' a baker feeds warm rolls and coffee to a couple who have just lost their only child. ''You have to eat and keep going,'' he says. ''Eating is a small, good thing at a time like this.''     But the...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser on a barbecue dinner with friends a few evenings after Sept 11; recipes for lamb chops and vanilla-bean cakes; photo; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In Raymond Carver's story ''A Small, Good Thing,'' a baker feeds warm rolls and coffee to a couple who have just lost their only child. ''You have to eat and keep going,'' he says. ''Eating is a small, good thing at a time like this.'' But the week of Sept. 11, eating, for once, was the last thing on my mind. A few days after the disaster, I was working on a story about vanilla -- vanilla as something rediscovered, a wonderful aromatic we often use but know very little about. I sat at my computer screen, with a wrinkled vanilla bean in hand and a cold cup of coffee at my side, wondering what I was doing.

docs.snippet: Jay Shaffer, left, who owns Shaffer City Oyster Bar & Grill, 5 West 21st Street, serves a variety of oyster that is his exclusively: Shaffer Cove, a plump, lightly briny medium-size bluepoint, above. This oyster has  a sweet finish, suggesting art...
docs.abstract: Jay Shaffer, who owns Shaffer City Oyster Bar & Grill, 5 West 21st Street, serves variety of oyster that is his exclusively: Shaffer Cove; oysters are from beds that he leases on North Shore, near Port Jefferson; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Jay Shaffer, left, who owns Shaffer City Oyster Bar & Grill, 5 West 21st Street, serves a variety of oyster that is his exclusively: Shaffer Cove, a plump, lightly briny medium-size bluepoint, above. This oyster has a sweet finish, suggesting artichokes, and a crisp texture. The oysters are bred from Wellfleet spat, transplanted to Great South Bay, near the Long Island town of Blue Point, and then transferred to beds that Mr. Shaffer leases on the North Shore, near Port Jefferson. The oysters are $2 each and can be ordered, freshly opened, to take out. To order: (212) 255-9827.

docs.snippet: Tuller Premium Food, 199 Court Street (Bergen Street), in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a tiny shop, so it chooses its cheeses carefully -- and there are gems among the 100 on display. They include Borough Market Stilton ($11.99 a pound); Cheddar and ...
docs.abstract: Tuller Premium Food in Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn offers 100 different types of cheese; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Tuller Premium Food, 199 Court Street (Bergen Street), in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, is a tiny shop, so it chooses its cheeses carefully -- and there are gems among the 100 on display. They include Borough Market Stilton ($11.99 a pound); Cheddar and Cheshire from England ($11.99 a pound); Pleasant Ridge Reserve, a Gruyère-style Wisconsin cheese ($16.99 a pound); and the Old Chatham Sheepherding Company's creamy new blue cheese, Ewe's Blue ($18.99 a pound). The store, owned by Robert Tuller, below, also sells Magnolia Bakery's ice creams ($3.99 a pint), rustic pastas from Italy and prepared foods, including excellent marinated roasted beets, parsnip purée and potatoes roasted in chicken drippings, all $5.99 a pound.

headline.main: In a Small Brooklyn Store, A Trove of 100 Cheeses

docs.snippet: Parisians don't celebrate Halloween as we do, but La Maison du Chocolat, the Parisian confectionery company, has gotten into the spirit with plump chocolate pumpkins garnished with an orange leaf. Inside are the real treats: morsels of delicious c...
docs.abstract: La Maison du Chocolat, Parisian confectionery company, gets into spirit of Halloween with plump chocolate pumpkins garnished with an orange leaf; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Parisians don't celebrate Halloween as we do, but La Maison du Chocolat, the Parisian confectionery company, has gotten into the spirit with plump chocolate pumpkins garnished with an orange leaf. Inside are the real treats: morsels of delicious caramelized toasted almond praline coated with milk or dark chocolate. Each pumpkin weighs 20 ounces and is $45. The almond morsels, Swiss Rocks, are also sold separately for about $3.50 an ounce. The company has sacks of small pumpkins and ghosts in milk or dark chocolate, too; $8 for four ounces, $16 for eight ounces. All are sold at 1018 Madison Avenue (78th Street) and 30 Rockefeller Plaza (on 49th Street). There is a new seating area in the Rockefeller Center store, where coffee, tea and dessert are served.

headline.main: From Paris, by Way of the Great Pumpkin

docs.snippet: A pound of spaghetti fits nicely into the new Bialetti pasta pot from Italy, which is oval in shape and holds four quarts of water. The lid, which clamps onto the rim, is studded with holes, turning the pot into its own colander and making it easy...
docs.abstract: New Bialetti pasta pot from Italy has colander in the lid; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A pound of spaghetti fits nicely into the new Bialetti pasta pot from Italy, which is oval in shape and holds four quarts of water. The lid, which clamps onto the rim, is studded with holes, turning the pot into its own colander and making it easy to drain the pasta when it is done. Sauce can then be added directly to the hot pasta. The interior of the heavy-gauge aluminum pot is lined with a type of Teflon that is not damaged by metal utensils. The Bakelite handles stay cool. The pot is also fine for boiling potatoes or other vegetables, and you can have any color you want, as long as it's metallic midnight blue. The pot costs $34.99 at Bed Bath & Beyond stores.

headline.main: A Pasta Pot That Puts The Colander in the Lid

docs.snippet: Anthony Perullo was on his way to becoming a doctor when he discovered medical school was not for him. Mr. Perullo, who has a degree in biochemistry from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, began to wonder why no one was making cheese...
docs.abstract: Anthony Perullo makes goat cheese under Captain Kid label in Mattituck, NY; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Anthony Perullo was on his way to becoming a doctor when he discovered medical school was not for him. Mr. Perullo, who has a degree in biochemistry from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, began to wonder why no one was making cheese in the flourishing wine country on the North Fork of Long Island. About a year ago Mr. Perullo, 34, jumped into the breach and now, with 18 goats on a small plot of land in Mattituck called Captain Kid Dairy, he is making several kinds of chèvre. His fresh chèvre is sold in a disk that weighs about a pound ($18). This is a mild cheese but has a nice tanginess. It's a lovely softish cheese to serve as you would a fromage blanc, with ripe berries, or even to use for a savory or sweet cheese cake.

headline.main: On the North Fork, 18 Goats Find Full-Time Jobs

docs.snippet: Though there may be enough variations on measuring spoons -- nonstick, narrow ones that fit into bottles and ones with odd measurements like 1 1/2 tablespoons -- yet another has broken into the field. Only there are no spoons involved. The Mini-Me...
docs.abstract: Mini-Measure, glass measuring cup, has measures for teaspoons and tablespoons; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Though there may be enough variations on measuring spoons -- nonstick, narrow ones that fit into bottles and ones with odd measurements like 1 1/2 tablespoons -- yet another has broken into the field. Only there are no spoons involved. The Mini-Measure is the size of a shot glass, and, like Pyrex measuring cups, it has measurements in bright red on the side. It will measure up to six teaspoons and two tablespoons, broken down by the one-half tablespoon. There are ounce measures and milliliters as well. If you've wrestled with a ring of measuring spoons while trying to pour droplets of almond extract into a teaspoon, you'll see the genius in this little glass. The Mini-Measure costs $6.50 for a pair at A Cook's Companions, 152 Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn; (718) 222-1868. AMANDA HESSER

headline.main: Measure for Measure, Minus the Spoons

docs.snippet: My mother would never put a carton of milk or juice on the table: they were decanted into pitchers.  I have the same habit, which is why I welcome Chiasso sleek stainless steel carton holders with rubber handles. The metal also helps keep the liqu...
docs.abstract: Comment on Chiasso stainless steel milk carton holders; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: My mother would never put a carton of milk or juice on the table: they were decanted into pitchers. I have the same habit, which is why I welcome Chiasso sleek stainless steel carton holders with rubber handles. The metal also helps keep the liquid cold. The cartons come in pint size ($24), quart size ($28) and half-gallon ($30). To keep the weight down, the half-gallon carton holder is actually stainless steel over aluminum. The holders are available from (800) 654-3570 or www.chiasso.com. Shipping is extra. There are Chiasso stores in cities around the country, including Boston and Short Hills, N.J., but there are none in Manhattan.

headline.main: Warning: Don't Try to Crush These Cartons

docs.snippet: On seaside terraces in Brittany, shellfish  are eaten with bread and salted butter. Just ask Maguy Le Coze, an owner of Le Bernardin, who is from Port Navalo in Brittany. Now, New Yorkers who want to indulge as the Bretons do can spread their brea...
docs.abstract: Correction of August 1 article on tuna fishing off East End of Long Island, NY
docs.lead_paragraph: On seaside terraces in Brittany, shellfish are eaten with bread and salted butter. Just ask Maguy Le Coze, an owner of Le Bernardin, who is from Port Navalo in Brittany. Now, New Yorkers who want to indulge as the Bretons do can spread their bread (preferably, brown) with Le Gall Beurre de Baratte au Sel de Guérande, a butter from Brittany that is churned with fleur de sel from the region. It is a deeper yellow than the salted butter in American supermarkets, and it blossoms on the palate with a more intense saltiness. You can actually taste the salt crystals in the butter. It is also excellent for pie crust because of its flavor and low moisture content. Next week, Citarella stores will have it, in an almost-9-ounce package for $4.29. Another Breton product made with salt comes in a surprise package. The box, 7 ounces, looks as if it should hold cheese, but it is candy, smooth little wrapped Caramels au Beurre Salé made by La Maison d'Armoine; $7.99 at Fairway.

headline.main: Caramels and Butter With a Taste of Breton Salt

docs.snippet: Ellen Byrne and Christopher Carlson, a husband-and-wife team, create chocolate bars suitable for framing: miniature paintings with crystallized leaves and flowers embellished with swirls, flourishes and precisely placed nuts. But their careful art...
docs.abstract: Ellen Byrne and Christopher Carlson, husband-and-wife team, create chocolate bars suitable for framing; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Ellen Byrne and Christopher Carlson, a husband-and-wife team, create chocolate bars suitable for framing: miniature paintings with crystallized leaves and flowers embellished with swirls, flourishes and precisely placed nuts. But their careful artistry can vanish in a few bites. The owners of Byrne & Carlson Chocolates in Portsmouth, N.H., they introduced their creatively decorated chocolate bars last year. They use delectable, intensely rich semisweet and bittersweet chocolate from Belgium, France and Venezuela and grow their own mint and pansies, which Mr. Carlson, a confectioner, crystallizes for the candy. The bars, each weighing 4 to 5 ounces, are $4 to $12 and also come in a set of four for $30. The line includes other candies like almond toffee, nut barks, and little dark chocolate wreaths called mendiants adorned with flowers, fruit and nuts, all sold at the shop at 121 State Street in Portsmouth, or by mail from (888) 559-9778. Shipping is extra.

headline.main: Don't Know Much About Art but Know What I Like to Eat
